question:
Who among the following was the slave-general of Alauddin Khilji, who led his army in the battle against Ramachandra of Devagiri?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Malik Kafur was the slave-general of Alauddin Khilji, purchased for 1000 dinars (Hazar Dinari).
  • He led the campaign against Ramachandra of Devagiri in 1307.
  • Ramachandra, the Yadava ruler, was defeated and later accepted Alauddin’s suzerainty.
  • This marked the beginning of Khilji expansion into the Deccan.

Additional Information:

  • Malik Kafur also led successful campaigns against southern kingdoms like Warangal, Dwarasamudra, and Madurai.
  • He became politically powerful in Alauddin’s court and played a role after his death.
  • His expeditions laid the foundation for Muslim rule in South India.

question:
Who introduced the system of Dagh and Huliyah and cash payment to soldiers in the Delhi sultanate?

SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji introduced the system of Dagh (branding of horses) and Huliyah (descriptive rolls of soldiers).
  • These measures were part of his military reforms to prevent corruption and ensure genuineness of soldiers.
  • He also started paying soldiers in cash instead of granting iqtas (land).
  • This improved efficiency, discipline, and central control over the army.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin Khilji’s reforms were aimed at strengthening the Sultanate’s military and checking rebellions.
  • He also enforced market reforms to control prices, enabling soldiers to live on fixed cash salaries.
  • These systems laid the groundwork for modern military bureaucracy in the subcontinent.

question:
During Alauddin Khilji's reign, the cloth market was known as ____________.

SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• During Alauddin Khilji’s reign, the cloth market was known as Sarai-i-Adl.
  • It was part of his market control system to regulate prices and eliminate black marketing.
  • Separate markets were set up for clothes, food grains, horses, and slaves.
  • These were supervised by market officials to ensure fair trade and price stability.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin Khilji appointed Shahna-i-Mandi (market superintendent) and Munhiyans (spies) to keep strict watch on markets.
  • These reforms were essential to support his cash-paid army by keeping prices low and stable.
  • Sarai-i-Adl ensured availability of quality cloth at fixed prices.

question:
By what name did Allauddin Khilji build his capital?

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji built his new capital by the name of Siri.
  • It was constructed to protect Delhi from Mongol invasions and to serve as a military and administrative centre.
  • Siri Fort was the second city of Delhi, built after Mehrauli (Lal Kot).
  • It was strategically designed with strong fortifications and garrisons.

Additional Information:

  • The construction of Siri was completed around 1303 AD.
  • Very little of Siri remains today, but its location is identified near modern-day Hauz Khas and Siri Fort area in Delhi.
  • Siri was known for housing Alauddin’s army and palace complex.

question:
Who was the first Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate to start military expeditions into southern India?

Matric Level 27/06/2023 (Shift - 1)
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji was the first Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate to begin military expeditions into southern India.
  • He sent his general Malik Kafur to lead campaigns against Devagiri, Warangal, Dwarasamudra, and Madurai.
  • These expeditions resulted in the submission of southern kingdoms and collection of huge war booty.
  • His campaigns marked the extension of the Delhi Sultanate’s influence into the Deccan and South India.

Additional Information:

  • The southern expeditions began around 1307 AD, starting with Devagiri (Yadavas).
  • Alauddin’s southern policy was aimed at wealth extraction rather than direct annexation.
  • The success of these expeditions significantly enriched the Delhi treasury.

question:
Who among the following was the founder of the Khilji Dynasty?

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Jalal-ud-din Firoz Khilji was the founder of the Khilji Dynasty in 1290 AD.
  • He overthrew the last ruler of the Slave Dynasty, Kaiqubad, to ascend the throne.
  • Jalal-ud-din was known for his mild and lenient policies, in contrast to his successor Alauddin.
  • His reign marked the beginning of Turko-Afghan rule under the Khiljis.

Additional Information:

  • He ruled from 1290 to 1296 AD and was assassinated by his nephew and son-in-law, Alauddin Khilji, who succeeded him.
  • The Khilji Dynasty became more expansionist and militaristic under Alauddin’s leadership.
  • Jalal-ud-din’s capital was located in Delhi.

question:
Which monument of Khilji dynasty in Delhi has the utilization of red sandstone?

SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Alai Darwaza is a monument built during the Khilji Dynasty in Delhi.
  • It was constructed by Alauddin Khilji in 1311 AD as the southern gateway of the Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque.
  • It is the first monument in India to extensively use red sandstone and true Islamic architectural elements like arches and domes.
  • It represents a significant development in Indo-Islamic architecture.

Additional Information:

  • The Alai Darwaza features intricate lattice work, calligraphy, and finely carved geometric patterns.
  • It stands inside the Qutub Complex in Mehrauli, Delhi.
  • The structure is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site along with the Qutub Minar.

question:
Which officer under Alauddin Khilji was required to maintain a register of merchants to ensure an adequate supply of goods?

SSC CGL Tier II (06/03/2023)
solution:
• The officer known as Shahna-i-Mandi was appointed under Alauddin Khilji to supervise markets.
  • He was responsible for maintaining a register of merchants and ensuring a regular supply of essential goods.
  • This post was a part of Alauddin’s strict market control system to regulate prices and check hoarding.
  • The Shahna-i-Mandi also ensured that traders sold at fixed prices and did not cheat buyers.

Additional Information:

  • Munhiyans (spies) were appointed to secretly report violations in the market.
  • The Muhtasib, a different official, ensured moral policing, not market regulation.
  • Alauddin’s economic policies were crucial for maintaining a cash-paid standing army.

question:
How many types of taxes were in the reign of the ruler Alauddin Khilji?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• During the reign of Alauddin Khilji, there were Three major types of taxes imposed on the people.
  • These included:
    1. Kharaj – land revenue (about 50% of the produce)
    2. Ghari – house tax
    3. Charai – tax on grazing

  • Other Taxes:

    1. Zakat – religious tax on Muslims
    2. Jizya – tax on non-Muslims
    3. Trade and market taxes – levied on goods and merchants
  • These taxes were part of his centralised revenue system to maintain his large standing army.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin Khilji abolished the Iqta system for nobles and started direct collection of land revenue.
  • He maintained detailed records and sent revenue officers to supervise the system.
  • His taxation was strict but ensured steady revenue for the administration.

question:
In which of the following years was Chittor attacked by Alauddin Khilji?

Higher Secondary 05/08/2022 (Shift-2)
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji attacked Chittor in the year 1303 AD.
  • The fort was ruled by Rana Ratan Singh of the Guhila (Sisodia) dynasty at that time.
  • After a prolonged siege, Alauddin captured Chittor and appointed his son Khizr Khan as the governor.
  • The event is famously associated with the legend of Rani Padmini and Jauhar (self-immolation) by Rajput women.

Additional Information:

  • Chittor was a strategically important fort in Rajputana, and its conquest gave Alauddin greater control over western India.
  • The story of Rani Padmini is mentioned in Malik Muhammad Jayasi’s epic poem “Padmavat”, though its historical authenticity is debated.
  • After the conquest, the fort was renamed Khizrabad for a brief period.

question: Who was the founder of the Khilji Dynasty?
solution:
• Jalaluddin Khilji was the founder of the Khilji Dynasty.
  • He established the dynasty in 1290 AD after overthrowing the last ruler of the Slave Dynasty.
  • Jalaluddin’s reign was marked by peaceful and lenient governance.
  • He was succeeded by his nephew and son-in-law, Alauddin Khilji, who made the dynasty more powerful and expansionist.

Additional Information:

  • Jalaluddin Khilji’s capital was Delhi.
  • The Khilji Dynasty was of Turko-Afghan origin.
  • The dynasty is known for its significant military and administrative reforms, especially under Alauddin.

question: The Khilji Dynasty replaced which previous dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate?
solution:
• The Khilji Dynasty replaced the Slave Dynasty (also known as the Mamluk Dynasty) in the Delhi Sultanate.
  • The transition occurred when Jalaluddin Khilji overthrew the last ruler of the Slave Dynasty, Kaiqubad, in 1290 AD.
  • The Slave Dynasty was the first dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, established by Qutb-ud-din Aibak.
  • The Khilji Dynasty introduced new administrative and military reforms under rulers like Alauddin Khilji.

Additional Information:

  • The Slave Dynasty ruled from 1206 to 1290 AD.
  • It was followed by the Khilji Dynasty, which ruled from 1290 to 1320 AD.
  • The Khilji rulers were of Turko-Afghan origin, whereas the Slave dynasty was mostly of Turkic slave origin.

question: Who assassinated Jalaluddin Khilji to capture the throne?
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji assassinated Jalaluddin Khilji to capture the throne of the Khilji Dynasty.
  • Alauddin was Jalaluddin’s nephew and son-in-law.
  • After killing Jalaluddin in 1296 AD, Alauddin seized power and became the Sultan of Delhi.
  • His reign marked significant military expansion and administrative reforms.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin Khilji was known for his strong centralised administration and market reforms.
  • He expanded the Delhi Sultanate’s territory to the south and defended it against Mongol invasions.
  • His assassination of Jalaluddin was a crucial turning point in the dynasty’s history.

question: The famous military general Malik Kafur was associated with the reign of:
solution:
• The famous military general Malik Kafur was associated with the reign of Alauddin Khilji.
  • Originally a slave, Malik Kafur rose to become a trusted general and commander under Alauddin.
  • He led successful campaigns in the Deccan, including expeditions against Devagiri, Warangal, and Madurai.
  • Malik Kafur also played an important role in the political affairs of the Sultanate after Alauddin’s death.

Additional Information:

  • Malik Kafur’s military achievements significantly expanded the Delhi Sultanate’s influence in South India.
  • He was known for his loyalty, military skill, and administrative capabilities.
  • Malik Kafur died shortly after Alauddin Khilji, which led to instability in the Khilji dynasty.

question: Which Khilji ruler launched expeditions into South India, reaching as far as Madurai?
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji was the Khilji ruler who launched military expeditions into South India, reaching as far as Madurai.
  • His general Malik Kafur led these campaigns during the early 14th century.
  • The expeditions resulted in the subjugation of several southern kingdoms including the Pandya kingdom at Madurai.
  • These campaigns extended the Delhi Sultanate’s influence deep into the Deccan and southern India.

Additional Information:

  • The southern campaigns aimed at collecting tribute and loot, rather than direct annexation.
  • Alauddin’s expansionist policies significantly increased the wealth and power of the Sultanate.
  • These expeditions demonstrated the military strength of the Delhi Sultanate in southern regions.

question: Alauddin Khilji’s Deccan campaign led to the submission of which important kingdom?
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji’s Deccan campaign led to the submission of several important southern kingdoms, including the Chola, Hoysalas, and Kakatiya dynasties.
  • His general Malik Kafur spearheaded these expeditions in the early 14th century.
  • These kingdoms were forced to pay tribute and accept the suzerainty of the Delhi Sultanate.
  • The campaign significantly expanded the Sultanate’s influence into the Deccan region.

Additional Information:

  • The expeditions were primarily for wealth extraction and establishing political dominance.
  • Alauddin’s campaigns did not result in permanent annexation but secured the submission of these kingdoms.
  • This marked a historic extension of northern Muslim rule into southern India.

question: The first ruler to introduce permanent standing army at the centre was:
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji was the first ruler to introduce a permanent standing army at the centre in the Delhi Sultanate.
  • He established a large, well-paid, and well-maintained army to ensure strong central control.
  • Soldiers were paid in cash salaries rather than land grants (iqta), which increased their loyalty to the Sultan.
  • This standing army helped Alauddin suppress rebellions and defend against Mongol invasions.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin’s military reforms included strict market control to keep prices low for soldiers.
  • The permanent army was a significant shift from earlier systems relying on feudal levies.
  • His army model influenced later Indian rulers and empires.

question: Alauddin Khilji’s Market Control policy mainly aimed at:
option_2: Preventing inflation and maintaining army supply
option_3: Promoting trade with Arabs
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji’s Market Control policy was primarily aimed at preventing inflation and maintaining a steady supply of goods for his cash-paid army.
  • He regulated prices of essential commodities like grains, cloth, and cattle to keep them affordable.
  • Strict measures, including appointing market supervisors (Shahna-i-Mandi) and spies (Munhiyans), were implemented to enforce these controls.
  • This policy ensured soldiers could sustain themselves on fixed salaries without economic hardship.

Additional Information:

  • Market control also helped Alauddin maintain central authority and suppress hoarding and black marketing.
  • The policy was unique and ahead of its time in medieval India.
  • It was integral to Alauddin’s larger administrative and military reforms.

question: What was the name of Alauddin Khilji’s market inspector?
solution:
• The name of Alauddin Khilji’s market inspector was Shahna-i-Mandi.
  • The Shahna-i-Mandi was responsible for supervising markets, ensuring the availability of goods, and enforcing price controls.
  • He maintained records of merchants and traders to prevent hoarding and black marketing.
  • This role was crucial for implementing Alauddin’s strict market control policies.

Additional Information:

  • The Shahna-i-Mandi worked alongside spies called Munhiyans who monitored the market secretly.
  • This system helped maintain price stability and supported the cash-paid army.
  • The position exemplifies Alauddin’s strong administrative control over the economy.

question: The term Dagh and Chehra, used for branding horses and soldier registration, was introduced by:
solution:
• The terms Dagh (branding of horses) and Chehra (soldier registration) were introduced by Alauddin Khilji.
  • These systems were part of his military reforms to prevent fraud and ensure the authenticity of soldiers and horses.
  • Dagh involved marking horses with a branded seal to verify ownership and condition.
  • Chehra was a detailed register containing soldiers’ descriptions to maintain an accurate army roster.

Additional Information:

  • These reforms helped Alauddin maintain a strong, disciplined, and loyal army.
  • The system prevented false claims of military service and horse ownership.
  • Such military innovations were crucial for Alauddin’s successful campaigns and control.

question: Which Mongol leader was defeated by Alauddin Khilji’s forces in India?
solution:
• The Mongol leader defeated by Alauddin Khilji’s forces in India was Qutlugh Khwaja.
  • Qutlugh Khwaja was a Mongol general who led invasions into the Delhi Sultanate during Alauddin’s reign.
  • Alauddin’s army successfully repelled these invasions, ensuring the Sultanate’s security from Mongol threats.
  • The battles against Qutlugh Khwaja demonstrated Alauddin’s strong military leadership.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin Khilji fortified the frontiers and maintained a large standing army to defend against Mongol invasions.
  • The Mongols under Qutlugh Khwaja were defeated in battles fought near Delhi and Punjab regions.
  • These victories prevented large-scale Mongol incursions into northern India.

question: Which region did Rani Durgavati rule before it was attacked by Khilji generals?
solution:
The correct answer is: c) Gondwana

  • Ruler: Rani Durgavati
  • Region: Gondwana (present-day Jabalpur, Mandla region, Madhya Pradesh)
  • Dynasty: Gond dynasty
  • Father: Chandel Rajput ruler Keerat Rai
  • Husband: Dalpat Shah (son of Gond ruler Sangram Shah)
  • Famous for: Brave resistance against Mughals under Akbar’s general Asaf Khan in 1564 CE.
  • Death: Fought till last breath; committed self-immolation (Jauhar) after being wounded to avoid capture.

Additional Information:

  • Capital: Garha-Katanga
  • Title: ‘Veerangana’ for her bravery in Indian history.

Note: No direct conflict with Khilji generals; question wording may confuse but correct match is Gondwana and Mughal invasion.

question: The Alauddin Khilji–Ranthambore campaign was directed against which Rajput ruler?
solution:
• The Alauddin Khilji–Ranthambore campaign was directed against the Rajput ruler Hammir Dev.
  • Rana Hammir Dev was the ruler of Ranthambore Fort, a stronghold in Rajasthan.
  • Alauddin Khilji launched the campaign to capture this strategic fort to consolidate his control over Rajasthan.
  • After a prolonged siege, Ranthambore was captured by Alauddin’s forces.

Additional Information:

  • The siege of Ranthambore took place around 1301 AD.
  • Rana Hammir Dev is remembered for his resistance against the Delhi Sultanate.
  • The capture of Ranthambore strengthened Alauddin’s position in northwestern India.

question: Who among the following was appointed as the governor of Gujarat by Alauddin Khilji?
solution:
• Alp Khan was appointed as the governor of Gujarat by Alauddin Khilji.
  • He was Alauddin’s brother-in-law and a trusted noble in his court.
  • Alp Khan was given the responsibility to administer Gujarat and maintain the Sultanate’s authority there.
  • His governance helped in consolidating Alauddin’s control over this important region.

Additional Information:

  • Alp Khan played a significant role in Alauddin’s administration and military campaigns.
  • His position as governor strengthened the Khilji dynasty’s influence in western India.
  • Later, Alp Khan was executed on charges of conspiracy during Alauddin’s reign.

question: Khilji architecture is best known for which significant modification in Alai Darwaza?
option_1: Use of marble domes
option_2: Use of true arch and dome
option_3: Blend of Chinese and Indian motifs
solution:
• Khilji architecture is best known for the introduction of the use of true arches and domes in the Alai Darwaza.
  • Built by Alauddin Khilji in 1311 AD, the Alai Darwaza is a gateway to the Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque in Delhi.
  • It was the first structure in India to use the true Islamic arch and dome construction techniques.
  • This architectural innovation marked a significant development in Indo-Islamic architecture.

Additional Information:

  • The Alai Darwaza is made of red sandstone and white marble.
  • It features intricate geometric patterns, calligraphy, and lattice work.
  • This monument represents a departure from earlier corbelled arch techniques used in Indian architecture.

question: Alauddin Khilji adopted the title of:
solution:
• Khilji architecture, especially under Alauddin Khilji, is renowned for pioneering the use of true arches and domes in India, a significant shift from the traditional corbelled arches used earlier.
  • The Alai Darwaza, built in 1311 AD as the southern gateway to the Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque in Delhi, stands as a landmark in Indo-Islamic architecture due to this innovation.
  • True arches are constructed using wedge-shaped stones (voussoirs) that evenly distribute weight, allowing for larger and more stable openings compared to corbelled arches. Similarly, true domes use a continuous curved surface rather than overlapping layers.
  • The incorporation of these architectural elements brought Indian Islamic architecture closer to Middle Eastern styles, enhancing both the structural integrity and aesthetic appeal of buildings.
  • The Alai Darwaza features red sandstone with white marble inlays, intricate geometric patterns, calligraphic inscriptions, and lattice work (jali), showcasing a blend of functionality and artistry.
  • This innovation influenced subsequent Islamic architecture across the Indian subcontinent and marks a turning point in medieval Indian architectural history.

Additional Information:

  • Prior to this, Indian architecture primarily relied on corbelled arches which were less stable and limited in scale.
  • The Alai Darwaza’s successful implementation of true arches and domes set a new standard and was emulated in later monumental structures such as the Qutub Minar complex and the Tughlaq tombs.
  • This architectural development also symbolized the growing sophistication and confidence of the Delhi Sultanate under the Khiljis.

question: Who was the last ruler of the Khilji dynasty?
solution:
• The last ruler of the Khilji dynasty was Khusro Khan.
  • Khusro Khan was originally a slave who rose to power after assassinating Mubarak Shah, the previous Khilji ruler.
  • His reign was short-lived, lasting from 1320 to 1320 AD (only a few months).
  • He was eventually defeated and killed by Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq, who founded the Tughlaq dynasty and succeeded the Khiljis.

Additional Information:

  • Khusro Khan’s rise marked the end of the Khilji dynasty’s rule over Delhi.
  • His rule was marked by political instability and internal conflicts.
  • The transition to the Tughlaq dynasty ushered in a new era in the Delhi Sultanate’s history.

question: The Khilji Dynasty came to an end in 1320 CE with the rise of:
solution:
• The Khilji Dynasty came to an end in 1320 CE with the rise of the Tughlaq Dynasty.
  • Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq defeated the last Khilji ruler, Khusro Khan, and established the new dynasty.
  • The Tughlaq dynasty marked the beginning of a new phase in the Delhi Sultanate with different administrative and military policies.
  • This transition brought more centralization and expansion under rulers like Muhammad bin Tughlaq and Firoz Shah Tughlaq.

Additional Information:

  • The Tughlaq dynasty ruled from 1320 to 1414 CE.
  • They are known for ambitious projects, including moving the capital and extensive campaigns.
  • The rise of the Tughlaqs ended the Khilji influence in northern India.

question: Alauddin Khilji forbade which of the following to strengthen his control over the nobles?
option_1: Marriage of nobles without permission
option_3: Inter-noble feasts and gatherings
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji forbade all of the following to strengthen his control over the nobles:
    • Marriage of nobles without his permission
    • Drinking liquor
    • Inter-noble feasts and gatherings
  • These prohibitions were part of his efforts to curb the power of the nobility and prevent conspiracies against his rule.
  • By controlling marriages and social interactions, Alauddin aimed to reduce the nobles’ influence and maintain a strong central authority.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin Khilji also imposed strict surveillance on the nobles and maintained a network of spies.
  • His policies ensured that the nobles remained loyal and less capable of rebellion.
  • These measures were unique in medieval India and contributed to the stability of his reign.

question: Which Khilji ruler introduced price control on grains, cloth, and horses to curb inflation?
solution:
• Alauddin Khilji introduced strict price control measures on essential commodities like grains, cloth, and horses to curb inflation.
  • His market reforms were designed to keep prices low and stable to support his cash-paid standing army.
  • Price control was enforced through appointed market officials (Shahna-i-Mandi) and spies (Munhiyans) to prevent hoarding and black marketing.
  • These controls helped maintain economic stability and strengthened central authority.

Additional Information:

  • Alauddin’s market regulations also included strict punishment for traders violating rules.
  • The policy was one of the earliest examples of state intervention in the economy in medieval India.
  • These reforms ensured that soldiers and common people could afford essential goods despite heavy military expenditures.
